abstract: There is nothing new about the medicinal use of the snail. The ancients and, in France at least, the not-so-ancients, made all sorts of claims for their efficacy. These ranged from the bizarre assertion that cooked snails from Africa, if eaten with wine, are good for stomachaches but only if an uneven number of them were served (Pliny) to the somewhat more rational enthusiasm found in 20th century French pharmaceutical texts. 1 Bonnemain B Helix and drugs: snails for western health care from antiquity to the present. Evid Based Complement Alternat Med. 2005; 2: 25-28 Crossref PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar These references are to the land-based varieties (Helix spp).
